metadata./Title: The histologic diagnosis and the management of cystic neutrophilic granulomatous mastitis: a case report

sections.Background:
Background Cystic neutrophilic granulomatous mastitis is a rare subtype of inflammatory mastitis characterized 
by a distinct histopathologic pattern, often associated with Corynebacterium species. This entity has been recently distinguished and should be differentiated from other types of chronic idiopathic mastitis due to its specific treatment.
sections.Case Presentation:
Case presentation A 44-year-old North African female patient, gravida 2, para 2, with no significant past medical 
history, presented with a 4-month history of a painful palpable mass in her left breast, with no history of trauma. 
Ultrasound imaging showed three lesions in the lower quadrant of the left breast, communicating with a superficial 
areolar abscess collection, creating a fistulous path to the skin. This ultrasound appearance was suspicious for sup purative mastitis; although, a necrotic tumor could not be ruled out. An ultrasound-guided needle biopsy revealed 
inflammatory and abscess features of the breast parenchyma without histological signs of malignancy. Steroid 
therapy and empirical antimicrobial treatment were started, and surgical excision was performed. Histologic features 
confirmed the diagnosis of cystic neutrophilic granulomatous mastitis. The patient recovered and was discharged due 
to clinical improvement.
sections.Conclusion:
Conclusion Cystic neutrophilic granulomatous mastitis is a recently defined entity, and its association with infection 
by Corynebacterium species can be detected by Gram stain and/or microbiological culture. Various treatment modalities are suggested, but the optimal treatment still requires further investigation.

sections.Introduction:
Introduction
Cystic neutrophilic granulomatous mastitis (CNGM) is 
a rare subtype of inflammatory mastitis characterized 
by a distinct histopathologic pattern, often associated with Corynebacterium species. The characteristic mor phologic features include suppurative lipogranulomas 
composed of central lipid vacuoles surrounded by neu trophils and an outer cuff of epithelioid histiocytes and 
Langhans-type giant cells.
This entity has been recently distinguished and should 
be differentiated from other types of chronic idiopathic 
mastitis due to its specific treatment. CNGM occurs in 
women during the period of genital activity and typically 
presents as a palpable, painful mass. Treatment is based 
on prolonged antibiotic therapy, which can be initiated 
even before microbiological findings are available. Some times, surgical treatment is required.Open Access

We present the clinicopathologic features of a case of 
CNGM and highlight the importance of recognizing this 
entity and the evidence of Corynebacterium-targeted 
therapy.
Case report
We describe a 44-year-old North African female patient, 
gravida 2, para 2, with no significant past medical history, 
who presented with a 4-month history of a painful palpa ble mass in her left breast, with no history of trauma.
This mass was tender to palpation, fistulized to the 
skin, and occupied the lower quadrants of the left breast. 
Ultrasound imaging showed three lesions in the lower 
quadrant of the left breast, measuring 35, 15, and 8 mm, 
communicating with a superficial areolar abscess collec tion, creating a fistulous path to the skin.
This ultrasound appearance was suspicious for suppu rative mastitis; although, a necrotic tumor could not be 
ruled out. An ultrasound-guided needle biopsy revealed 
inflammatory and abscess features of the breast paren chyma without histological signs of malignancy. Based 
on these findings, steroid therapy and empirical antimi crobial treatment were started, and surgical excision was 
performed.
Direct bacteriological examination was negative, and 
histologic study showed non-necrotizing granuloma tous inflammation electively located in the lobules with 
cystic-like spaces (Fig.  1). The inflammatory infiltrate was 
mainly composed of neutrophils, lymphocytes, and mult inucleated giant cells surrounding round cystic spaces 
(Fig.  2). With these findings, the diagnosis of CNGM was 
established.The treatment administered included amoxicillin/
clavulanic acid 1000 mg three times daily for 1 week, 
with no improvement observed. This was followed by 
clarithromycin 250 mg twice daily for 15 days, and then 
doxycycline 200 mg daily for 3 months. Corticosteroid 
therapy was initially given at a dose of 60 mg per day for 
1 month, followed by a gradual tapering over the subse quent 2 months.
The patient recovered and was discharged due to clini cal improvement. She returned for a consultation, four 
months later, showing a favorable progress and signifi cant further improvement.
sections.Discussion:
Discussion
CNGM is an increasingly recognized entity character ized by suppurative lipogranulomas composed of neu trophilic and granulomatous inflammation surrounding 
central lipid vacuoles. We aim to bring attention to this 
new entity, which can be unrecognized and requires spe cific treatment. The diagnosis is based on clinical and his topathological criteria [1, 2]. Gautham et al. summarized 
the criteria for diagnosing CNGM [2], which include 
clinical criteria such as a female patient around the 
fourth decade of life, with mammary tumors and a poor 
or partial response to initial empirical antibiotic treat ment (for example, antituberculous treatment). Histolog ical criteria include cystic-looking spaces surrounded by 
mixed inflammation, predominantly neutrophilic, with 
noncaseous granulomas and the presence of Gram-pos itive bacilli or corynebacteria (verified by Gram stain or 
culture). There are no universally accepted diagnostic cri teria in the literature [3]. These cystic spaces result from 
central lipid vacuoles and some of them may contain

Fig. 2 Lobocentric inflammatory granulomas composed

Gram-positive bacilli identified as Corynebacterium spe cies [4].
This pathogen can be detected either by microbiologi cal culture or by tissue Gram staining on formalin-fixed 
paraffin-embedded histological sections [2]. Micro biological evidence of Corynebacterial infection can be 
challenging to prove. CNGM occurs more frequently 
in parous or currently pregnant female patients with a 
mean age of 35 years [3]. Clinically, it presents as painful 
swelling of the breast, nipple discharge, or skin erythema 
mimicking an orange-peel appearance of the breast. 
Radiologically, ultrasound may reveal a mass, edema, or 
fluid collection [3]. However, the most common mam mographic features are masses and asymmetry, often 
classified as suspicious of malignancy (BI-RADS 4) [3].
The differential diagnosis for CNGM includes other 
granulomatous diseases such as mycobacterial infections 
causing tuberculosis mastitis, sarcoidosis, foreign body 
reaction, and autoimmune diseases. Regarding treat ment, management options include empirical antibiotics, 
immunosuppressive therapy, and/or surgical interven tions. The gold standard treatment for CNGM has not 
yet been established.
Conclusion
In summary, CNGM is a recently defined entity that 
should be distinguished from idiopathic granulomatous 
mastitis. This condition has a strong association with 
infection by Corynebacterium species, which can be 
detected by Gram stain and/or microbiological culture. 
Patients can be managed with various treatment modali ties, but the optimal treatment still requires further 
investigation.
